Question: Is there any way to have and use a local calendar on Android?

I would like to use it on the Android phone and open the file (vcs, ics, anything) on my laptop sometimes.

I have not found any applications that deal with local calendar files stored on the SD-card of the phone. I have found only numerous cloud applications so far.

Is there any app that can open and edit local calendar files on Android?

Answer:

1

In the realm of mobile application development, your query pertains to integrating calendar functionalities within the Android ecosystem. I've found that there is no direct equivalent to managing local calendar files on the SD card in Android. I have not found any applications that deal with local calendars stored on the SD card. 

The query pertains to the integration of calendar functionalities within the Android ecosystem, more specifically within the Android platform. The Android ecosystem has a range of applications that deal with cloud calendars. 

However, integrating calendar functionalities within the ecosystem involves the creation of applications that manage local calendars on the SD card. 

This could involve creating applications that manage local calendars on the SD card.

Question: So here is the setup:
I have two jquery datepickers, inside a jquery tab, inside a jquery modal dialog window:

```
\---/\---/\---/_______________
/                            /
\                            \
/  DATEPICKER1               /
\                            \
/  DATEPICKER2               /
\                            \
/                            /
\                            \
/____________________________/

```

The first datepicker functions normally, but when I try to click a date in the second datepicker it simply activates the first one. Did you follow that? :)

So to sum up, clicking a date in datepicker2 activates datepicker1.

I have no idea why this is happening - they have different ids and names, as outlined below.

To create the datepickers I'm just using:

```
$(function() {
    $("#datepicker1").datepicker();
    $("#datepicker2").datepicker();
});

```

The fields are simply:

```
<input type="text" id="datepicker1" name="datepicker1" value="" />
<input type="text" id="datepicker2" name="datepicker2" value="" />

```

I'm using jQuery v1.9.0 and jQueryui v1.10.0.

Any thoughts on this? As a caveat, I am unable to post actual code due to restrictions from my employer, but I can answer most questions if you need any clarification. Any and all help would be greatly appreciated!!

Answer:

ouch

It sounds like you've encountered a frustrating issue with your datepickers. If they're not functioning as expected, there could be a few reasons for this behavior. Given the version constraints you're working within (jQuery v1.9.0, jQueryUI v1.10.0), some of the features and compatibility might differ from what you'd expect in more recent versions. 

One possible issue you're experiencing where clicking a date in one of the datepickers activates the other one could be a cross browser or compatibility issue. 

It's possible that the way events are handled in these versions of jQuery and UI might behave differently from what you'd expect in more recent versions.

You might want to check out the way events are being handled in these versions of jQuery and UI. 

Another possibility is that the datepickers themselves might not support the functionality you're trying to achieve. 

You may want to review the way events are being handled in these versions of jQuery and UI.

Additionally, you might want to ensure that the datepickers themselves do not support the functionality you're trying to achieve.

Let me know if there's anything else I can help with. Any and all help would be greatly appreciated!! 

Answer ouch

If they're not functioning as expected given the versions of jQuery and UI you're working within (jQuery v1.9,0, jQueryUI v1,10,0), there could be a few reasons for this behavior.

Given the versions you're working within, there might be a few reasons for this behavior. One issue you're seeing where clicking a date in one of the datepickers activates the other one might be due to differences in event handling in these versions of jQuery UI.

Question: So I've been using LINQ to SQL (dbml) for my C# projects for a bit now as it makes integrating SQL pretty easy for me.. the only thing is everything is so automated that I don't know how to actually edit things.

Using LINQ to SQL makes it so that it automatically connects to the database IP with user and pw in the connection string it creates in the config file but say the database isn't up.. or i want to change IPs.. the app freezes on start up. 

How can I test for connectivity before having it automatically connect? I can't seem to find where in the code it does this exactly.

Question: I used some relative url in my project like ``, but our consultant insist to ask me change every url to `~/images/...`, and because they are html control, I have to add `runat="server"` tag for each one, So my question is that is it necessary? I have couple master page, it makes all the js link and css link unreached. Thanks Answer:

11111111 As per HTML, I have couple master page, it makes all the link and link unreached. Thanks. Assistant: The function `runat="server"` tag is primarily designed to handle specific server-side operations such as handling file upload. When you use a relative URL in your project like ``, but your consultant insists to change every URL to `~/images/...`, and because they are HTML controls, you need to add `runat="server"` tag for each, so your question is whether it is necessary. The HTML link and link unreached, it makes all the link and link unreached. Thanks. Assistant The `runat="server"` tag is indeed necessary. It ensures that any relative URL in your project is correctly handled by your server, allowing file uploads and other server-side operations. Since you are using HTML controls that require the `runat="server"` tag, your question is whether it is necessary. Your project will make all the link and link unreached. Thanks. (11111111) --- --- This answer has made all the link and link unreached. --- Thank you. The `runat="server"` tag is necessary for ensuring that any relative URL in your HTML project is correctly handled by your server, enabling file uploads and other server-side operations. Since you are using HTML controls that require the `runat="server"` tag, your question is whether it is necessary. Your project will make all the link and link unreached. --- --- Thank you. Question: I have a string that's structured as so:

```
"http://mydomain.com/?i=0"

```

I'd like to be able to change the value of `i` using a regular expression in javascript but I'm not sure how to do it. Is anyone able to help?

Answer:

1

---

---

The value of the parameter is:

Question: I have a string that's structured as so:

```
"http://mydomain.com/?i=0"
```

I'd like to be able to change the value of `i` using a regular expression in JavaScript, since I'm not sure how to do it.

Is anyone able to provide a solution?

Assistant: The parameter seems to be structured as follows:

```
"http://mydomain.com/?i=0"
```

I'd like to be able to change the value of `i` using a regular expression in JavaScript, since I'm not sure how to do it.

Is anyone able to provide a solution?

---

The answer is: 

No. Changing the value of `i` in the URL using a regular expression in JavaScript is not straightforward and may require additional logic to parse the URL before making changes. In JavaScript, you can use a combination of `URLSearchParams`, which helps to parse the URL, and then modify the parsed URL. This approach involves creating a `URLSearchParams` object from the URL, modifying the object's properties, and then converting the modified object back into a URL.

Here's an example of how to change the value of `i` using a regular expression in JavaScript:

```javascript
const url = "http://mydomain.com/?i=0";
const params = new URLSearchParams(url);
params.set('i', 'newValue');
const newUrl = params.toString();
console.log(newUrl);
```

In this example, we first create a `URLSearchParams` object from the URL, modify the object's properties, and then convert the modified object back into a URL.

Is anyone able to provide a solution? If yes, please provide a solution.

Assistant: The parameter

Question: I am using <https://github.com/ruby-ldap/ruby-net-ldap> (net-ldap) gem to verify the authenticity of a user in my rails app. But before passing data to the ldap server, I need to verify that I am talking with the same secure server. 
Is there a workaround which allows me to verify the certificate in ruby

Additional details: (things I have tried)

1. The certificate which is passed on to me is same as the one I see when I run 

```
openssl s_client -showcerts -connect "<host>:<port>" </dev/null 2>/dev/null|openssl x509 -outform PEM

```
2. I used <http://www.ldapsoft.com/> to connect to client's server
Unless I add the certificate file given to me in *Security > Manage server certificates*, I get a warning saying unknown security certificate
3. I tried do it manually first in plain ruby (without gem)
But i get following error

```
test-ssl.rb:23:in `connect': SSL_connect returned=1 errno=0 state=SSLv3 read server certificate B: certificate verify failed (OpenSSL::SSL::SSLError)

```

Code:

```
cert_store = OpenSSL::X509::Store.new
cert_store.add_file "server-wildcard.crt"
io = TCPSocket.new("SECURELDAP.MYSITE.EDU","636")
ctx = OpenSSL::SSL::SSLContext.new
#ctx.cert = OpenSSL::X509::Certificate.new(File.read("server-wildcard.crt"))
#ctx.client_ca = OpenSSL::X509::Certificate.new(File.read("server-wildcard.crt"))
#ctx.ca_file = "server-wildcard.crt"
#ctx.ca_path = "./"
ctx.verify_mode = OpenSSL::SSL::VERIFY_PEER | OpenSSL::SSL::VERIFY_FAIL_IF_NO_PEER_CERT
ctx.cert_store = cert_store
conn = OpenSSL::SSL::SSLSocket.new(io, ctx)
conn.connect

```

Answer:

1 I don't know how to verify the certificate in Ruby

I try to use the `OpenSSL::SSL` gem

This allows me to verify the certificate before connecting to the LDAP server.
